questions.text: A young patient was operated on for a brain tumor. Following surgery, it is found that there is an injury to the hypothalamus. All of the following anterior pituitary hormones are likely to be decreased in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Following damage to the hypothalamus, all the hormones secreted by the anterior pituitary will decrease except prolactin. 

The hypothalamus plays an important role in controlling the hormones released from the anterior pituitary. It mainly stimulates the production of all the other anterior pituitary hormones except prolactin. It inhibits prolactin production by releasing prolactin inhibitory hormones. 

Therefore, any injury to the hypothalamus or damage to the hypothalamic-hypophysial portal system, the levels of other anterior pituitary hormones are decreased, while the prolactin levels are increased.

Prolactin is secreted by the lactotropes of the anterior pituitary. Structurally it is similar to human growth hormone and human chorionic somatomammotropin (hCS).

Levels of prolactin are increased during exercise, surgical and psychological stresses, stimulation of the nipple, sleep, pregnancy, thyrotropin-releasing hormone, etc.

The important function of prolactin is to cause milk secretion and prevent ovulation in a lactating mother. It increases the production of casein and lactalbumin. Increased prolactin decreases the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormones, and subsequently decreases the secretion of gonadotropins. 

Clinical correlation - Dopamine released from the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus decreases the secretion of prolactin. Therefore, L dopa which is a precursor of dopamine decreases prolactin secretion, and dopamine antagonists like chlorpromazine and antipsychotics increase the prolactin secretion.

questions.text: The lung compliance of a 40-year-old patient with shortness of breath has been compared to that of a normal person in the pressure-volume curve below. What is the likely diagnosis based on this chart?
questions.solution:
The interpretation of the above pressure-volume curve shows that the patient has increased lung compliance, making the likely diagnosis of pulmonary emphysema. 

Compliance is the tendency for tissue to resume its original position after an applied force has been removed.

After an expiration during quiet breathing, the lungs have a tendency to collapse and the chest wall has a tendency to expand. The interaction between the recoil of the lungs and the recoil of the chest can be measured through a spirometer and a curve of airway pressure plotted against volume is the pressure-volume curve of the total respiratory system (Ptr).

Compliance of the lung and chest wall is measured as the slope of the PTR curve, or, as a change in lung volume per unit change in airway pressure (ΔV/ΔP). 

  • The curve is shifted downwards when compared to normal in case of decreased compliance. Eg. pulmonary edema, and interstitial pulmonary fibrosis due to alveoli being prevented from getting inflated. Decreased compliance is also seen in sarcoidosis.
  • The curve is shifted upwards and to the left in case of increased compliance. Eg. emphysema, normal aging lungs due to decreased elastic recoil of lungs (a tendency of the lungs to become less stretched).

 

Increased compliance seen in emphysema is due to - 

Related Pearl: Lung Compliance

Compliance is the change in lung volume per unit change in the surrounding pressure.

It is represented by the formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Factors Affecting Compliance

  • Lung volume: smaller the lungs, smaller is the compliance
  • For a given lung size, the compliance becomes less at extremes of lung volume
  • Compliance is slightly greater when measured during deflation than during inflation
  • If the surface tension is more, compliance is less
  • Compliance measured with saline is more than compliance measured with air.

Compliance is decreased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis: Due to increased fibrous tissue in the lung, making it less elastic, and thus less expandable.
  • Alveolar edema, which prevents the expansion of some alveoli.
  • If lung remains unventilated for a long time, in a low volume lung, due to atelectasis (collapse) of lung units or increased surface tension.
  • Increased pulmonary venous pressure.

Compliance is increased in conditions such as:

  • Pulmonary emphysema
  • Normal aging lung

questions.text:
The structures involved in the auditory pathway are -
  1. Superior olivary nucleus
  2. Nucleus of the medial lemniscus
  3. Superior colliculus 
  4. Medial geniculate body
  5. Superior temporal gyrus
questions.solution:
The structures involved in the auditory pathway are 1, 4, and 5, i.e, the superior olivary nucleus, medial geniculate body, and superior temporal gyrus.

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is -

  1. Vestibulocochlear nerve
  2. Cochlear nucleus
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex - superior temporal gyrus

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text: Doppler flowmetry of the brain in a 28-year-old patient showed increased cerebral blood flow. Cerebral blood flow is increased in all of the given situations except:
questions.solution:
Cerebral blood flow is increased in all of the above situations except for raised intracranial pressure.

As brain tissue and spinal fluid are essentially incompressible, the volume of blood, spinal fluid, and brain in the cranium at any time must be relatively constant (Monro- Kellie doctrine). Therefore, if the intracranial pressure increases, cerebral vessels get compressed. Hence, an increase in intracranial pressure compromises cerebral blood flow. 

Normal cerebral blood flow is around 50-65mL/100g of brain tissue/min. 

  • Factors that increase cerebral blood flow
    • Increased H+ ion concentration which causes vasodilation of cerebral vessels
    • Increased arterial pCO2 that combines with water to form carbonic acid and release H+ ions
    • Substances that decrease the pH in the blood like lactic acid, pyruvic acid etc 
    • Hypoxia immediately increases blood flow as brain is sensitive to even slightly low levels of oxygen drop
    • Substances released from astrocytes- NO, K+, adenosine, etc 

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region.

questions.text:
An elderly man presents with weakness in his lower limbs. On motor examination, the resident taps on the patellar tendon with a knee hammer and there was a sudden kicking movement of the knee. Which of the following is true about the given reflex?
  1. It is a monosynaptic stretch reflex
  2. Root value of the reflex is L5 - S2
  3. Glycine is the neurotransmitter 
  4. The afferent is carried via group Ia fibres from the muscle spindle
  5. Efferent is acted upon γ-motor neurons of the hamstring muscles
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, the resident is performing a knee jerk reflex (patellar reflex) on this patient. Statements 1 and 4 are correct about this reflex.

Knee jerk or patellar reflex is elicited by tapping the patellar tendon resulting in contraction of the quadriceps muscle. It is an example of a deep tendon reflex or myotatic stretch reflex as stretching the muscle causes reflex contraction. 

The reflex arc in the knee jerk reflex consists of only one synapse between afferents and efferents. Hence, it is also an example of a monosynaptic reflex. 

Reflex arc of knee jerk reflex -  

Tapping the tendon causes a stretch of the muscle spindle which is present within the muscle. The muscle spindle is a sensory proprioceptor responsible for identifying the length of the muscle fibers. The Ia afferent sensory fibers in the muscle spindles are activated in response to the stretch. These Ia afferent fibers go to the spinal cord at the dorsal root ganglia and stimulate the alpha-motor neurons. This results in the contraction of the muscle that was initially stretched. The neurotransmitter at the central synapse is glutamate.

The femoral nerve L2-L4 mediates the patellar reflex.

 

Clinical aspect: 

  • Brisk, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes are seen in upper motor neuron lesions affecting the descending spinal tracts like the corticospinal tract. 
  • Hypoactive or absent reflexes are seen in lower motor neuron lesions or the lesions affecting the components of the reflex arc. Absent reflexes can be seen in diabetes, deep sleep, coma, nerve block, spinal anesthesia etc. 
  • The pendular knee jerk, in which tapping the patellar tendon results in to-and-fro movements of the limb is seen in cerebellar lesions. The increased swinging occurs due to hypotonia of both flexors and extensors leading to a lack of restraint on each other.

questions.text: In the following pressure-volume loop diagram of left ventricle, the mitral valve will close at the point:
questions.solution:
The closure of the mitral valve corresponds to point 2, which marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

 The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • Point 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • Point 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • Point 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • Point 4 - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling:  

  • In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point 1 to point 2.
  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume which corresponds to about 50 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B, the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume which corresponds to about 120 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve closes.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction:

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumetric contraction lasts from point 2 to point 3.
  • At point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) and then the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point 3 to point 4.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of relaxation lasts from point 4 to point 1.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 ml of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text: After a meal, the plasma levels of insulin has peaked in a person. Which of the following glucose transporters would facilitate the uptake of glucose by the skeletal muscles mediated by insulin?
questions.solution:
The glucose transporter that would facilitate the uptake of glucose by the skeletal muscles mediated by insulin is GLUT-4.

Normally, a pool of GLUT-4 molecules is maintained within vesicles in the cytoplasm of the insulin-sensitive cells. When the insulin receptors in them are stimulated, the vesicles move rapidly and fuse themselves to the cell membrane and facilitate the transport of glucose molecules into the cells.

This GLUT-4 receptor is also present in cardiac muscle and adispose tissues.

questions.text: Stimulating which of the following hypothalamic nuclei will lead to increased appetite?
questions.solution:
Stimulating lateral hypothalamic nuclei is will lead to increased appetite and food intake. 

The lateral hypothalamus is generally known as the hunger center, and its main function is the stimulation of feeding behavior and appetite. Excessive stimulation of these nuclei causes a voracious appetite, whereas any lesion here produces a profound loss of appetite, weight loss, and decreased metabolism.  

Other options - 

Option A - Ventromedial hypothalamic nucleus, also known as the satiety center gives a sense of satisfaction or fullness and inhibits the feeding center. 

Option C - Anterior hypothalamic nuclei are responsible for regulating the body temperature. 

Option D - Suprachiasmatic nucleus controls the diurnal variation of ACTH, and also regulates the circadian rhythm.

questions.text: Which of the following has the lowest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation?
questions.solution:
Among the fetal blood vessels mentioned above, the superior vena cava (SVC) has the lowest oxygen concentration. It carries deoxygenated blood from the upper part of the body to the right atrium.

The pO2 of SVC is about 12-14 mm Hg whereas the pO2 of the umbilical artery is about 20-25 mm Hg. This is because the SVC carries only deoxygenated blood, whereas the umbilical artery carries a mix of oxygenated blood from ascending aorta and deoxygenated blood from systemic circulation.

Fetal circulation:

The blood gets oxygenated in the placenta and this passes to the umbilical vein. From the umbilical vein, 50% of the blood enters the hepatic circulation and 50% bypasses the liver to enter the inferior vena cava. Thus, the inferior vena cava, which also carries blood from hepatic veins, kidneys, and from lower extremities, carries a mixture of deoxygenated and oxygenated blood. So, the highest percentage of oxygen in fetal circulation is in the umbilical vein, followed by the inferior vena cava. 

The blood then enters the heart via the right atrium. The right atrium also receives purely deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava. This blood then enters the pulmonary artery. Since fetal lungs are collapsed, most of the blood enters the descending aorta via ductus arteriosus and is then distributed to the body. 

Finally, some of this blood from the aorta and the lower parts of the body is pumped back to the placenta via umbilical arteries. Hence, they contain a mix of both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text:
Match the following sodium channels to their sites of reabsorption in the nephron:
Site Transport channel
1. Early proximal convoluted tubule A. Na+–2Cl-–K+ cotransporter
2. Thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle B. Epithelial sodium channels (ENaCs)
3. Distal convoluted tubule C. Sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT) 
4. Collecting duct D. Na+-Cl- cotransporter
questions.solution:
The correct option is Option C: 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B. 

Reabsorption of sodium in different parts of the nephron are:

  • Proximal convoluted tubule (PCT): 
    • Nearly 60% of the filtered sodium is reabsorbed in the PCT. Solutes mainly absorbed in the proximal tubule are sodium, chloride, bicarbonate, phosphate, lactate, glucose, amino acids etc. 
    • In early PCT, the main sodium channels used for reabsorption are Na+-glucose cotransporter (SGLT), Na+-H+ exchanger, Na+-amino acid cotransporter, Na+-phosphate cotransporter, etc. 
    • In distal PCT, due to high chloride concentration in the lumen, it favors NaCl reabsorption, driven by Cl− gradient. 
    • The total solute and water reabsorption are proportional to each other. Thus, the entire proximal tubule also reabsorbs nearly 60% of the filtered water (isosmotic reabsorption). 
  • Loop of Henle:
    • The thin descending limb has no active transport of Na+ outside the lumen but the loop is permeable to water, making the tubular fluid hypertonic.
    • A thick ascending limb reabsorbs nearly 30% of the Na+ by Na–2Cl–K cotransporter, an example of secondary active transport. This loop is impermeable to water. Since some of the solutes are reabsorbed and water is not reabsorbed, it dilutes the tubular fluid. Other ions like Ca 2+, and Mg2+ are also absorbed here. 
  • Distal convoluted tubule: Approximately 7% of the filtered load of sodium chloride is reabsorbed in the early distal tubule. This occurs due to the presence of sodium chloride co-transporter. Even this segment dilutes the tubular fluid as it is impermeable to water. 
  • Cortical collecting tubule: The remaining 3% of the filtered Na+ is absorbed via ENaCs (epithelial sodium channels) in this duct.  This portion is regulated by aldosterone to maintain homeostasis in Na+ balance.

Clinical aspect: 

i) Barrter syndrome is a congenital renal disorder due to mutation in Na–2Cl–K cotransporter, ROMK K+ channel, ClC–Kb Cl− channel, or barttin. It is characterized by chronic urinary Na+ loss, with hypovolemia, hypokalemia, and alkalosis.

ii) Gitelman syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder affecting the sodium chloride co-transporter in the distal tubules, leading to decreased sodium chloride reabsorption. 

iii) Liddle syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder where mutation results in increased activity of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in the distal and collecting tubules. This leads to increased reabsorption of sodium and water causing hypertension and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: The image below shows finding seen on eliciting plantar reflex in a patient in the neurology ward. All of the following signs may be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The image shows extensor plantar response (positive Babinski sign), suggestive of an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion. Fasciculations are seen in lower motor neuron lesions (not UMN).
 
UMNs refer to corticospinal tract neurons and brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. Injury to UMNs lead to:
  • Spasticity
  • Hypertonia 
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski sign).
Babinski sign refers to dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes when the lateral aspect of the sole of the foot is scratched. It is a sign of an upper motor neuron lesion. In normal adults, the response is plantar flexion of all the toes.
 

The image below shows a positive Babinski sign in an adult, which is abnormal and indicative of a UMN lesion. 

In infants whose corticospinal tracts are still underdeveloped, dorsiflexion of the great toe and fanning of other toes is a normal response to scratching of the sole of the foot.

The image below shows an extensor response in an infant, which is normal.

questions.text: The graph below shows the variations in the levels of an adrenocortical hormone over a period of 24 hours. Excessive synthesis of this hormone can lead to which of the following features?
questions.solution:
The adrenocortical hormone likely plotted above is cortisol as the graph shows a diurnal variation with the maximum peak occurring around 8.00 AM. Excessive synthesis of this hormone leads to decreased cellular immunity. 

Cortisol suppresses cellular immunity by inhibiting the production of IL-2 and decreasing the proliferation of T-lymphocytes. This action is used for suppressing immunity by administering exogenous glucocorticoids to reduce the rejection reactions during transplantation.  

Cortisol is secreted in a pulsatile fashion and has a diurnal variation in its level. The maximum level occurs in the morning just before awakening (at around 8.00 AM). It gradually declines later and the lowest levels are seen in the evening and midnight, after falling asleep. 

Cortisol is the major glucocorticoid hormone synthesized in the adrenal cortex, mainly in the zona fasciculata layer. Its actions are - 

i) Metabolic effects:

  • On carbohydrates: It stimulates gluconeogenesis, increases glycogen synthesis, and decreases the utilization of glucose in peripheral tissues. Thus, excess stimulation of cortisol causes hyperglycemia. 
  • On fat: Increases lipolysis. 
  • On protein: Exerts a catabolic effect and causes proteolysis
  • Effect on appetite: Increases the appetite and food intake by inducing the synthesis of neuropeptide-Y.

ii) Anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects:

  • Induce the synthesis of lipocortin, an inhibitor of phospholipase A2
  • Inhibit the release of histamine and serotonin 
  • Inhibit the production of IL-2 and T lymphocytes, and depresses cellular immunity

iii) Maintenance of vascular responsiveness to catecholamines:

  • Cortisol up-regulates α1 receptors on arterioles, increasing their sensitivity to the vasoconstrictor effect of norepinephrine, thereby causing hypertension in hypercortisolism. 

iv) Bone formation inhibition by decreasing the type 1 collagen synthesis, intestinal calcium absorption, and osteoblastic activity. 

v) In the central nervous system, cortisol receptors are majorly found in the limbic system. Hence, stimulation of this decreases the rapid eye movement during sleep and increases awake time. Thus, high levels of cortisol are seen in the morning just before awakening.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia and was prescribed ferrous fumarate tablets for 2 months. Which of the following channels help in the absorption of this iron taken orally into the enterocyte?
questions.solution:
The channel that helps in the absorption of the iron into the enterocyte is divalent metal transporter 1 (DMT1). Transport of iron across the brush border of the intestinal cells in the ferrous form is accomplished by DMT-1, also known as natural resistance-associated macrophage protein type 2 (Nramp 2). 

The mechanism of iron absorption and transport - 

Iron is available in food in two forms, heme and nonheme. Heme iron is mainly present in red meat and is readily absorbed. This iron is mainly absorbed from the duodenum and proximal small intestine. The acidic contents of the stomach play a major role in absorption. Once it reaches the brush border of the absorbing cell, the ferric form is converted to ferrous form by ferrireductase. This ferrous form is then transported into the cell by divalent metal transporter type 1 (DMT-1). 

Once inside the cell, iron may be stored as ferritin or transported to plasma through ferroportin. During the transport, iron is converted back into the ferric form by hephaestin and ceruloplasmin. The iron in plasma is then transferred to the required tissues with the help of protein transferrin. Iron is a major content of hemoglobin, myoglobin, cytochrome P-450 group of enzymes, components of electron transport chain, and ribonucleotide reductase.

Hepcidin, a protein secreted from the liver plays a major role in the regulation of iron absorption. When the body’s iron stores are adequate, it downregulates the expression of ferroportin and thereby decreases iron absorption.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was detected with a positive antibody titer against the thyroid peroxidase enzyme. All of the following steps are catalyzed by this enzyme for the synthesis of thyroid hormones except?
questions.solution:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. Oxidation, organification, and coupling are catalyzed by it.  

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I- (iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. The process of concentrating iodide in the cell is known as iodide trapping. Iodide is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter.
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by the thyrocytes and secreted into colloid.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation: TPO oxidizes iodine in the presence of H2O2
    • Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes in the colloid from the thyroid cells. This releases thyroxine and triiodothyronine into the peripheral blood. 
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has a report showing HCO3- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L. Calculate the anion gap in this patient.
questions.solution:
The anion gap in this patient is 22 mEq/L.

Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, a few of the anions (lactate, phosphate, and sulfate) cannot be measured and this is called an anion gap. It is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Plasma anion gap = [Na+ ] − [(HCO3− ) + (Cl− )]

Substituting the values = 145−23−100= 22 mEq/L

The normal anion gap ranges between 8-16 mEq/L.

questions.text: A randomized control study was conducted on 100 people to determine the causes and effects of different hormones that increase insulin secretion. All of the following factors increase insulin secretion except?
questions.solution:
Somatostatin decreases insulin secretion. Acetylcholine, gastric inhibitory polypeptide (GIP), and arginine stimulate its release.

Somatostatin, also known as growth hormone-inhibitory hormone, is secreted by the delta cells of the islets of Langerhans. It acts locally to inhibit insulin and glucagon secretion, reducing tissue utilization of absorbed nutrients. The primary function of somatostatin is to prevent the rapid depletion of nutrients, ensuring their availability over an extended period.

Insulin, secreted by the pancreatic beta cells, responds to increased blood glucose levels by promoting glucose uptake, storage, and utilization. When blood glucose levels rise, insulin:

  • Enhances hepatic uptake of glucose, storing it as glycogen
  • Facilitates the conversion of excess glucose into fatty acids
  • Suppresses glycogen breakdown to maintain glucose homeostasis

Conversely, when blood glucose levels fall, insulin secretion decreases, activating phosphorylase to break down glycogen and release stored glucose into circulation.

Mechanism of Insulin Secretion

  1. Glucose Entry: Glucose enters pancreatic beta cells via GLUT-2 receptors.
  2. Phosphorylation: Inside the cell, glucokinase (rate-limiting enzyme) phosphorylates glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, which is then oxidized to generate ATP.
  3. Potassium Channel Closure: Increased ATP levels close ATP-sensitive potassium channels, leading to cell depolarization.
  4. Calcium Influx: Depolarization triggers the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels, causing Ca²⁺ influx.
  5. Insulin Release: Elevated intracellular Ca²⁺ levels stimulate the exocytosis of insulin-containing vesicles, releasing insulin into the bloodstream.

Other Options:

Option B: Acetylcholine stimulates M3 receptors, which increases Ca²⁺ , which leads to increased insulin. Hence, Acetylcholine promotes insulin secretion during the cephalic phase of digestion (before food intake).

Option C: GIP is an incretin hormone K-cells release in the small intestine in response to oral glucose intake. It binds to β-cell receptors and increases cAMP, which enhances insulin secretion.

Option D: Arginine is an amino acid that stimulates β-cells directly.

questions.text: An individual takes a deep breath of 100% oxygen from mid-inspiration and then expires through a rapidly recording nitrogen meter. This produces the recording shown in the image below. What does this test measure?
questions.solution:
The test described is the single-breath N2 test which is used to measure the dead space volume, and the image shown is the single-breath N2 curve.

From mid-inspiration, the patient inhales 100% oxygen as deeply as possible, then exhales steadily while the N2 content of the expired gas is continuously measured using a nitrogen meter. The recording obtained is the single-breath N2 curve.

  • Phase I of the curve: Initial gas exhaled that was present in the dead space. It does not contain any N2.
  • Phase II: A mixture of dead space and alveolar gas
  • Phase III: Alveolar gas. It terminates at the closing volume (the lung volume above residual volume at which lower airways begin to close due to lesser transmural pressure)
  • Phase IV: The N2 content of the expired gas is increased.

The volume of the dead space is the volume of the gas that is expired from peak inspiration to the midportion of phase II. The total dead space can be calculated using Bohr's equation. 

The anatomic dead space refers to the respiratory system volume exclusive of alveoli, and the total (physiological) dead space is the volume of gas not equilibrating with blood i.,e. wasted ventilation. In healthy individuals, the two dead spaces are almost equal and can be estimated by body weight. The normal dead space air in a young adult man is around 150 mL.

Other options - 

Option B: Forced vital capacity, a dynamic lung measurement from spirometry is the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort. Forced expiratory volume in the first second, FEV1, is the fraction of the vital capacity that is expired during the first second.

 

Option C: Tidal volume (TV) is measured with the help of a diagnostic spirometer. It is the amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration during quiet breathing. The normal values are 500-750 mL.

questions.text: A young female patient is undergoing evaluation for infertility. The gynecologist collects the cervical mucus and spreads it on the microscope. It shows the following appearance. The patient had her periods 22 days back. Which of the following statements is true regarding this patient?

choices.text: This finding occurs due to progesterone
She is in mid luteal phase

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding this patient is that she has not ovulated. The presence of a fern pattern of cervical mucus on the 22nd day of her menstrual cycle indicates that she has not ovulated. 

Estrogen makes the cervical mucus thinner and more alkaline to promote easy survival and transport of sperm. When the mucus is spread on the slide, it shows the fern pattern. After ovulation and during pregnancy, the levels of progesterone rise and this hormone makes the cervical mucus thick. The ferning pattern will no longer be seen. 

The mucus is thinnest at the time of ovulation due to the increased levels of estrogen. It can be stretched into a long, thin thread that may be 8–12 cm or more in length. This is called the spinnbarkeit phenomenon.

Before ovulation, the phase is known as the preovulatory phase or the follicular phase of the cycle. The uterus is undergoing proliferative changes, hence it is also known as the proliferative phase. After ovulation occurs, the corpus luteum secretes estrogen and progesterone and this phase is known as the luteal phase or secretory phase. In this phase, the uterus is vascular, and edematous with coiled glands.

 The tests for ovulation are:

  • The body temperature decreases during ovulation and increases by 1/2 to 1°F. This is due to the thermogenic action of the progesterone.
  • Endometrial biopsy- usually done 1-2 days before menstruation. The presence of secretory changes in the endometrium suggests that ovulation has occurred. 
  • Fern test- The appearance of a fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus leading to the loss of fern pattern.
  • Ultrasound- used to monitor the maturation of the Graffian follicle and ovulation.
  • Hormonal studies - Increased levels of plasma progesterone (~15 ng/mL) in the mid-luteal phase (22–23rd day) suggest that ovulation has occurred and determination of LH surge.

questions.text: A student was asked to record ECG by using bipolar limb leads. The below image shows the arrangement of the bipolar electrodes and the potentials recorded across lead I and lead II. What is the potential recorded across lead III?
questions.solution:
According to Einthoven’s law, the potential recorded across lead III is +0.7 mV.

Einthoven’s Law: Einthoven’s law states that if the ECGs are recorded simultaneously with the three limb leads, the sum of the potentials recorded in leads I and III will equal the potential in lead II.

Lead I potential + Lead III potential = Lead II potential

Lead III = Lead II – Lead I = (1.2-0.5) = +0.7 mV.

Note: Einthoven's triangle is an imaginary triangle drawn around the area of the heart. It is formed by the arrangement of three bipolar limb leads (the two arms and left leg).

questions.text: During research on male contraceptives, a group of scientists was studying the blood-testis barrier.  This barrier is located between:
questions.solution:
The blood-testis barrier is located between Sertoli cells and Sertoli cells.

Sertoli cells are linked by tight junctions, the strongest intercellular barrier in the body. This arrangement forms the blood-testes barrier.

Important functions of the blood testes barrier are:

  • It prevents the passing of large molecules from interstitial tissue and basal compartment to the tubular lumen.
  • It helps in maintaining the composition of the tubular fluid.
  • It protects the developing sperms from immunological attack and blood borne noxious agents.

questions.text: The pupillary light reflex is being assessed in a child with suspected cranial nerve palsy. Which two cranial nerves are being tested here?
questions.solution:
The 2nd and 3rd cranial nerves are being tested during the pupillary light reflex. The afferent of pupillary light reflex is the 2nd cranial nerve and the efferent is the 3rd cranial nerve.

When light is shone in one eye, the pupils of both eyes constrict. 

  • Constriction of the pupil of the same eye is called direct reflex.
  • Constriction of the contralateral pupil is called consensual reflex/indirect reflex. 

Pupillary light reflex pathway:

  • First-order neurons (sensory) connect each retina with both pretectal nuclei in the midbrain at the level of the superior colliculi. The sensory fibers are carried through the optic nerve. 
  • Second-order neurons (internuncial) connect each pretectal nucleus to bilateral Edinger–Westphal nuclei.
  • Third-order neurons (preganglionic motor) connect the Edinger–Westphal nucleus to the ciliary ganglion. These parasympathetic fibers pass via the oculomotor nerve. 
  • Fourth-order neurons (postganglionic motor) leave the ciliary ganglion and pass into the short ciliary nerves to innervate the sphincter pupillae in both eyes.

questions.text:
The lung function of a patient is tested using a spirometer, and the following recording is noted. The technician looks at the graph and enters the following values in the report.
Volumes Values
1. Tidal volume  500 mL
2. Inspiratory reserve volume 2L
3. Expiratory reserve volume 1L
4. Inspiratory capacity 4.5L
5. Expiratory capacity 1.5L
6. Vital capacity 3.5L

Which among the following capacities has been incorrectly calculated by the technician?
questions.solution:
The technician has recorded inspiratory reserve volume, inspiratory capacity, and vital capacity wrongly.

In the above graph, 

Tidal volume (TV) is the amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration during quiet breathing. In this patient it is 0.5L. The normal values are 500-750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the tidal volume. In this patient, it is 6-3L = 3L. The normal values are around 2L.

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration. In this patient it is 2.5-1.5 = 1L. The normal value is around 1L.

Inspiratory capacity (IC) is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level. It can be calculated as TV+IRV which is 0.5L + 3L= 3.5L. The normal value is around 2.5L.

Expiratory capacity (EC) is the maximum amount of air expired after a normal inspiration. It is calculated as TV+ERV, which is 0.5L + 1L = 1.5 L. Normal value is around 1.5L

Vital capacity (VC) refers to the maximum amount of air expired after full inspiration. It is calculated as TV+IRV+ERV. In this patient it is 0.5+ 3+1 =4.5L. The normal value is around 3.5L.

Other important lung values:

The forced vital capacity (FVC), is the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort.

Forced expiratory volume in the first second, FEV1, is the fraction of the vital capacity expired during the first second. 

Respiratory minute volume (RVV) is a measurement of the amount of air that enters the lungs per minute. It is calculated as respiratory rate X tidal volume.

Maximal voluntary respiration (MVV), is the largest volume of gas that can be moved into and out of the lungs in 1 min by voluntary effort.

Total lung capacity is the total volume of the lung. It can be calculated by adding tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume. Normal total lung capacity is around 5L.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man with a known history of bronchial asthma presented with acute breathlessness, tachycardia, and agitation. Pulse oximetry was 85% on room air. Identify the correct sequence of events that are occurring in the carotid bodies in response to the current state.
  1. Inactivation of potassium channels
  2. Depolarization
  3. Decreased efflux of potassium
  4. Excitation of afferent nerve
  5. Calcium influx
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma where the patient is hypoxic (pulse oximetry of 85%). The correct sequence regarding the response to hypoxia is 1-3-2-5-4.

Type I glomus cells in the carotid and aortic bodies have O2-sensitive K+ channels, which are inactivated in response to hypoxia. This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ inﬂux, via L-type voltage-gated calcium channels. The Ca2+ influx triggers action potentials and consequent excitation of the afferent nerve endings.

The smooth muscle cells in the pulmonary arteries contain similar O2-sensitive K+ channels, which mediate the vasoconstriction caused by hypoxia. Systemic arteries contain ATP-sensitive K+ channels that allow K+ efflux in response to hypoxia leading to vasodilation instead of vasoconstriction.

Since there is a large blood flow per unit of tissue in the carotid bodies, the O2 needs of the cells are met largely by dissolved O2 alone. The receptors are not stimulated in anemia or carbon monoxide poisoning, since the dissolved O2 in the blood reaching the receptors is generally normal, even though the combined oxygen in the blood is decreased.

The receptors are stimulated when:

  • Low arterial Po2 
  • Vascular stasis- the amount of O2 delivered to the receptors per unit time is decreased
  • Cyanide - prevents O2 utilization at the tissue level
  • Nicotine in sufficient doses activates the chemoreceptors
  • Infusion of K+ increases the discharge rate in chemoreceptor afferents

questions.text: A normal healthy adult participated in a respiratory study that was conducted to understand the respiratory functions. In the upright position, an increase in all of the following parameters can be seen with respect to the base of the lungs except?
questions.solution:
In the upright position, an increase in the ventilation-perfusion ratio (V/Q ratio) is not seen with respect to the base of the lungs. At the base of the lung, the V/Q ratio is decreased. 

V/Q ratio is the ratio of alveolar ventilation (V) to pulmonary blood flow (Q) for the lungs at rest. The average value of the V/Q ratio throughout the lungs is 0.8. When this ratio is mismatched, it can cause CO2 retention (when solely, ventilation is impaired) or lowered arterial O2 (when perfusion is impaired). 

Normally, in the upright position, the V/Q ratio in the normal lungs markedly undergoes changes from the apex to the base due to the effect of gravity as shown below - 

At the base of the lung:

Both ventilation and perfusion increase since the flow is towards gravity.

Increased ventilation is due to the increase in intrapleural pressure compared to the apex, thereby making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference less at the base. Thus, due to this low-pressure difference, the lung is less expanded compared to the apex. This makes the ventilation per unit volume rise as the lung expansion is relatively small. 

The alveolar pressure also decreases thus reducing the compression of the vessels and increasing the pulmonary blood flow at the base. An increase in perfusion is more than an increase in ventilation, i.e., denominator increases. Hence, the ratio decreases.

At the apex (against gravity):

Both ventilation and perfusion decrease since the flow is against gravity.

The reason for decreased ventilation is that at the start of inspiration, intrapleural pressure is more negative thus making the intrapulmonary intrapleural pressure difference increase at the apex. The apex is above the level of the heart and capillary pressure at the apex is close to atmospheric pressure thus decreasing the blood flow. But, a decrease in perfusion is higher than a decrease in ventilation. Hence, the ratio increases.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing an evaluation for shortness of breath. A test to assess the diffusing capacity of the lungs is done. This is measured using one of the following gas components?
questions.solution:
The diffusion capacity of the lungs is measured with carbon monoxide (CO).

The diffusing of CO is diffusion-limited and hence the diffusion capacity for CO called DLCO is measured as an index of diffusing capacity of the lung.

The diffusing capacity of the lung for a given gas is directly proportional to the surface area of the alveolar-capillary membrane and inversely proportional to its thickness.

In this test, a small amount of CO is used to measure the alveolar gas exchange during a 10-second breath-hold. The CO in exhaled breath is then analyzed and the quantity of CO that crosses the alveolar membrane is determined. The normal value of DLco at rest is about 25 mL/min/mm Hg.

DLCO is decreased in patients with:

  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Emphysema (chronic bronchitis usually have normal DLCO)

DLCO is increased in patients with:

  • Obesity
  • Asthma
  • Pulmonary hemorrhage
  • Exercise

questions.text: An oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve of a 30-year-old athlete was recorded. If curve 3 represents the dissociation curve during rest, how would the graph shift if he was exercising?

questions.text: The agglutination test of a 2-day-old baby born to an Rh-negative mother is given below. The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of?
questions.solution:
The baby is at the risk of having hemolytic reactions due to the presence of the D antigen. The given agglutination test shows agglutination only with the Rh antiserum. The Rh antigen in the given options is the D antigen.

From the given agglutination test, the blood group of the baby is O-positive, as there is agglutination with the Rh antiserum, but no agglutination with A or B antisera. 

Rh alloimmunization occurs when an Rh-negative mother produces antibodies to Rh antigens due to an Rh-positive fetus. 

In an Rh-positive individual, the presence of the D antigen is specific and carries antigenic properties responsible for hemolytic reactions. 

There are six common types of Rh antigens (C, D, E and c, d, e) each of which is called an Rh factor. The type D antigen is more antigenic than the others. Individuals who have the type D antigen are said to be Rh-positive, whereas those who don't have it are Rh-negative.

ABO blood typing is performed by mixing the individual's red blood cells with antisera that contains the various agglutinins on a slide and observing for the presence of clumping or agglutination.

The H antigen is present in all four blood groups (A, B, AB, and O). A rare blood group where there is an absence of the H antigen is known as the Bombay blood group. Absence of this H antigen results in absence of A and B antigens. Their plasma contains anti-A, anti-B, and strong anti-H antibodies. Therefore, they do not react with anti-A, anti-B, and anti-AB antiserums, and get recognized as O blood group on cell typing.

Thus if a patient with the Bombay blood group is transfused with the O blood group blood, the anti-H antibodies in the Bombay blood group patient react with the H antigen present in the O blood group. This can lead to fatal transfusion reactions. Therefore, patients with the Bombay blood group require the same blood group during transfusion.

questions.text: You ask a patient to breathe normally and then expire forcefully to measure the lung volumes and capacities using a spirometer. Which of the following cannot be measured using this method?
questions.solution:
Total lung capacity (TLC) cannot be measured by a spirometer.

Total lung capacity is the total volume of the lung. It can be calculated by adding tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume. Normal total lung capacity is around 5.8 L. 

TLC = IRV+ TV+ ERV+ RV

A spirometer does not measure the residual volume (RV), therefore it cannot be used to measure the lung capacities such as functional residual capacity (FRC) and total lung capacity (TLC), which include the residual volume. Residual volume is the amount of air remaining in the lung after forceful expiration. As we cannot expire this air, thus it cannot be directly measured by spirometry. 

Residual volume, FRC, and TLC can be measured by - 

  • Helium-dilution method
  • Body plethysmography

questions.text: In a patient, a recording of jugulovenous pressure was assessed by the resident and he tried correlating it with the patient's heart sounds. Which of the following heart sound occur just after this pressure waveform marked by the arrow?
questions.solution:
The heart sound occurring just after the pressure waveform marked by the arrow is S1. The waveform marked in the image is 'a wave' and it corresponds to atrial contraction.

S1 (first heart sound) is heard in the isovolumetric contraction phase of the cardiac cycle where ventricles contract against closed mitral valves. This occurs after atrial systole, corresponding to 'a' wave in the jugular venous pressure. Thus, S1 can be heard just after the 'a' wave. 

Jugular venous pressure measured in the internal jugular vein (IJV) is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. IJV is preferred because it is not valved and is in direct line with the superior vena cava and right atrium. 

 

The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are:

  • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just before the first heart sound.
  • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular systole.
  • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.
  • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound.
  • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid valve opening.

The Wiggers diagram given below correlates JVP with other aspects of the cardiac cycle. 

Other options - 

Option A: S4 is heard in the phase of atrial systole where atria contract in the late stage of ventricular filling. This occurs just before S1 and 'a' wave in the JVP. 

Option B: S3 is heard in the passive ventricular filling phase where mitral valves are open. It is seen after the 'v' wave peak in the JVP. 

Option D: S2 is heard due to the closure of aortic and pulmonary valves in the isovolumetric relaxation phase after ventricular systole. It can be heard just before the 'v' wave corresponding to the JVP waveform.

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 40-year-old man has left-sided CN III palsy and right-sided hemiplegia. Visual field testing reveals right homonymous hemianopia and Wernicke's hemianopic pupillary reaction. Which of the following represents the site of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes Wernicke's hemianopic pupil reaction. The site of lesion in the Wernicke hemianopic pupil is the optic tract.

Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is an abnormal light reflex. Here, illumination of the blind half of the retina shows no pupillary reaction while illumination of the normal half of the retina shows a pupillary reaction. It is seen in lesions involving the optic tract.

Lesions of the optic tract cause blindness in half of the visual field, known as homonymous hemianopia. Homonymous hemianopia involves loss of vision on the same side of the visual field in both eyes. Optic tract lesions also present with contralateral CN III palsy and ipsilateral hemiplegia, due to the proximity of the crus cerebri and CN III. 

Common causes of optic tract lesions- 

  • More commonly due to secondary lesions of the optic tract such as chordomas, pituitary adenomas, tentorial meningiomas, aneurysms, etc. 
  • Primary lesions of the optic tract such as syphilitic meningitis or gumma, tuberculosis or tumor of optic thalamus or temporospenoidal lobe

  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: The following process where transportation is along the concentration gradient is an example of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows a glucose transporter that transports glucose from a higher concentration to a lower concentration. This is an example of facilitated diffusion. 

When carrier proteins help in the movement of substances in the direction of their chemical or electrical gradients (downhill movement), no energy input is required and the process is called facilitated diffusion.

Glucose transporters also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitated diffusion. Facilitated diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions inside the cell membrane by binding to a carrier/ transport protein. 

For example, insulin stimulates glucose entry into the cells via facilitated diffusion by increasing the number of glucose transporters (GLUTs) in the cell membrane. This type of insulin-dependent glucose transport via GLUT 4 is observed in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues. 

Other options - 

Option A. Simple diffusion - It is along the concentration gradient but is not carrier-mediated. In the cell, examples of molecules that can use simple diffusion to travel in and out of the cell membrane are water, oxygen, carbon dioxide, and nitrogen. They pass directly through the cell membrane without energy along the concentration gradient.

Option C. Primary active transport - It is a form of cellular transport requiring energy in the form of hydrolysis of ATP to ship and transfer molecules against a membrane with chemical or electrical gradient differences. The important examples of primary active transport include sodium-potassium ATPase, proton pump, and calcium ATPase.

Option D. In secondary active transport, the active transport of sodium is coupled to the transport of other substances. Examples include the symport of sodium with glucose (luminal membranes of mucosal cells in the small intestine), and Ca2+ in the cardiac muscle cells.

questions.text: A boy presented to the emergency with severe rice-watery diarrhea and dehydration. Upon investigating, he was diagnosed to have cholera. On which of the following enzymes in the intestinal tract does the cholera toxin act?
questions.solution:
Cholera toxin acts on the adenylyl cyclase enzyme. The diarrhea is due to the action of this toxin that acts by stimulating the enzyme adenylate cyclase, which catalyzes the production of cyclic AMP from ATP. 

Mechanism of action of cholera toxin: 

The cholera toxin is made up of an active (A) subunit, and a receptor binding (B) subunit. B subunit attaches to the GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells. Once bound, the entire toxin complex is endocytosed by the cell and the A subunit is released inside. This A subunit then binds to the stimulatory Gα-coupled receptor causing activation of cellular adenylate cyclase which catalyzes the production of cyclic AMP from ATP. 

High levels of cAMP start a cascade leading to overactivity of the cell resulting in outpouring of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the lumen. This is the reason for rice-watery diarrhea which is isotonic with plasma but contains much more potassium and bicarbonate. The toxin also inhibits the intestinal absorption of sodium and chloride.

All clinical manifestations and complications in cholera result from the massive water and electrolyte depletion thus caused.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented after an episode of acute gastroenteritis and was infused with fluids. A while later, after fluid infusion, his heart rate rose to 122 bpm and he complained of palpitations. The presence of tachycardia can be explained by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The presence of tachycardia can be explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

It is a compensatory cardiac reflex where there is an increase in the heart rate in response to raised atrial stretch.

In fluid overload states, commonly after excessive fluid infusion, there is distension of the atria due to increased blood volume. This distension activates the atrial stretch receptors which transmit the afferent signals to the medulla via the vagus nerve. The efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves. This leads to an increase in the strength of contraction of the heart and tachycardia. This reflex helps in preventing excess accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and in the pulmonary circulation.

Other options - 

Option A: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region. They can be elicited after administering certain irritants like capsaicin or serotonin. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography. This reflex is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. 

Option B: Pulmonary chemoreflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung. This produces reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Option D: Cushing's reflex is seen when the intracranial pressure is raised where the blood supply to ventrolateral medulla neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia stimulate the neurons producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

 

Note: Bainbridge reflex causes tachycardia, whereas all the other mentioned reflexes predominately cause bradycardia.

questions.text: While measuring the blood pressure of an 80-year-old man, it was found that the pulse pressure was wide. Assuming he has no other co-morbidities, and that it is due to age-related changes, what is the physiology behind this widened pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Pulse pressure increases with age due to decreased arterial wall compliance. 

Diastolic blood pressure falls after 60 years of age due to increased arterial stiffness and decreased compliance, often associated with arteriosclerosis. As the left ventricle contracts against stiffer, less compliant arteries, systolic blood pressure also increases. 

As a result of these two changes, pulse pressure increases (↑PP = ↑SBP - ↓DBP) 

The factors that affect the pulse pressure:

  • the stroke volume output of the heart 
  • the compliance or total distensibility of the arterial walls
  • the character of ejection from the heart during systole (less important)

Pulse pressure = Stroke volume/ arterial compliance

Widened pulse pressure (> 40 mm Hg) occurs with several diseases such as:

  • Aortic regurgitation
  • Aortic sclerosis
  • Severe iron deficiency anemia 
  • Arteriosclerosis 
  • Hyperthyroidism 

In the majority of these cases, systolic pressures increase while diastolic pressures remain near normal.

questions.solution:
Rapidly adapting receptors that sense 128 Hz (fast vibration) are Pacinian corpuscles.

Pacinian corpuscles are cutaneous mechanoreceptors, which consist of unmyelinated dendritic endings of a sensory nerve fiber, encapsulated by concentric lamellae of connective tissue. It gives them an onion peel-like appearance. They respond to deep pressure and fast vibration of frequencies ranging between 60 - 300 Hz. These adapt very slowly and therefore, are important for signaling continuous states of deformation of the tissues, such as heavy prolonged touch and pressure signals. They are also found in joint capsules and help to signal the degree of joint rotation.

Option D - Meissner’s corpuscles are elongated encapsulated nerve endings of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber. They are abundant in the nonhairy parts of the skin (lips, fingertips). Meissner's corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors, particularly sensitive to the movement of objects over the surface of the skin, as well as to low-frequency vibration (5-40 Hz).

questions.text: The excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) are respectively caused by:
questions.solution:
The excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) and inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) are caused by Na+ influx and Cl- influx, respectively.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true about the skeletal muscle contraction?
  1. Extracellular Ca2+ is not important for contraction
  2. Ca2+ is released from mitochondria
  3. Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
  4. Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels on sarcolemma have no role in excitation-contraction coupling
questions.solution:
During the contraction of the skeletal muscle, the Ca2+ is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. Only statement 3 is correct.

Excitation-contraction coupling refers to the process by which the membrane depolarization of the muscle fiber (excitation) leads to the contraction of the muscle.

The steps of excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle are as follows:

  • Motor-neuron discharge causes the release of acetylcholine at the motor endplate, which binds to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors.
  • This causes increased Na+ and K+ conductance in the endplate membrane, leading to the generation of end-plate potential, which is a local potential.
  • When the local endplate potential reaches a threshold for the muscle fiber, an action potential is generated.
  • The generated action potential passes inward through the T tubules, leading to the spread of depolarisation.
  • The depolarization of the muscle fiber causes the release of Ca2+ from terminal cisterns of the sarcoplasmic reticulum and diffusion to thick and thin filaments.
  • The calcium released, binds to troponin C, uncovering myosin-binding sites on actin.
  • The formation of cross-linkages between actin and myosin and sliding of thin on thick filaments causes contraction of the skeletal muscle.

Steps in relaxation:

  • The cytoplasmic calcium is pumped back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, by the action of SERCA (sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase).
  • Once the calcium concentration is lowered, the interaction between actin and myosin ceases, and the muscle relaxes. 
Other options:
 
Statement 1: Incorrect - Extracellular calcium levels play an important role in muscle contraction. When there is a decrease in extracellular calcium as in hypocalcemia, the voltage-gated sodium channels are activated, which causes sodium influx. The increased intracellular sodium concentration causes sustained depolarization, which may lead to tetany.
 
Statement 2: Incorrect - Ca2+ is not released from mitochondria. It is released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
 
Statement 4: Voltage-gated calcium channels on the sarcoplasmic reticulum are activated by a depolarizing stimulus, which causes the release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum. The increased calcium concentration will eventually lead to muscle contraction.

questions.text: A young male patient presented to the casualty after a road traffic accident and was diagnosed with intracranial hemorrhage on the CT brain. He was started on hypertonic saline. Which of the following images best depict the changes in the fluid volumes after administration of the given saline?
questions.solution:
After the administration of hypertonic saline, the changes in the fluid volume occur as depicted in image 4.

The clinical features depict raised intracranial pressure due to intracranial haemorrhage. Patients are started on osmotic diuretics like mannitol or hypertonic saline to prevent cerebral swelling. The administration of the osmotic agents increases the osmolarity of the plasma. The cerebral tissues have lower osmolarity compared to the plasma. Therefore, this leads to the flow of excess water from cerebral tissues to the blood via osmosis.

Whenever hypertonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid (ECF), the extracellular osmolarity increases. It causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment. Almost all the added sodium chloride remains in the extracellular compartment and fluid diffuses into the extracellular space to achieve osmotic equilibrium. The net effect is that the volume of ECF increases, the volumes of intracellular fluid (ICF) decreases, and the osmolarity of both compartments increase. 

Whenever isotonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid, the osmolarity of fluids does not change. The main effect is that it increases the ECF volume

Whenever hypotonic saline is added to ECF, the osmolarity of ECF decreases. This leads to the movement of water from the ECF to the ICF until both attain the same osmolarity. Both the intracellular and extracellular volumes are increased by the addition of hypotonic fluid, but the intracellular volume increases to a greater extent. Osmolarity decreases in both the compartments.

questions.text: A person experiences heat in her left hand on touching a hot vessel on the stove. In the pathway that carries this sensation of temperature to the brain, the axons of which order neurons cross to the right side?
questions.solution:
In the pathway that carries temperature from the site of sensation to the brain, the axons of second-order neurons cross to the opposite side of the spinal cord.

The pathway that is responsible for conveying the sensations of pain and temperature is the lateral spinothalamic tract. The following are the order of neurons in this tract.

  • First-order neurons - Neurons in the dorsal root ganglia. 
    • These neurons synapse with the neurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
  • Second-order neurons - Neurons in the gray matter of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
    • The axons of these neurons cross to the opposite side of the spinal cord at the same level at which the sensation is perceived. They ascend up and synapse with the neurons in the thalamus
  • Third-order neurons - Neurons in the thalamus.
    • Their axons then relay in the postcentral gyrus of the cerebral cortex

questions.text: Following a road traffic accident, the patient sustained an injury to the right half of the spinal cord. Which of the following features is likely to be seen in this patient below the level of the lesion?

choices.text: Loss of pain and temperature on the right side
Muscle weakness in the left side of the body
Loss of vibration and proprioception on the right side
Loss of vibration and proprioception on the left side

questions.solution:
The feature likely to be seen in this patient below the level of the spinal cord lesion is loss of vibration and proprioception of the right side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown- Séquard syndrome. The features likely to be seen here are - 

  • Ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion. It occurs as a result of damage to the fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus
  • Ipsilateral muscle weakness as a result of damage to the corticospinal tract
  • Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the lesion as a result of damage to the spinothalamic tract.

Corticosteroids administered soon after the injury help in preventing the damage.

Other important syndromes related to the ascending tracts of the spinal cord are

  • Paresthesias are the abnormal sensation of numbness or tingling sensation in the body. It is usually caused due to the irritation of the primary somatosensory cortex.
  • Thalamic pain syndrome is characterized by chronic pain on the side of the body contralateral to the stroke. It occurs during the recovery from the thalamic infarct.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A 27-year-old patient presents to the OPD with nystagmus, scanning-type of slurred speech, and intentional tremors. He also displays ataxia when asked to walk across the examination room as given below. This is likely due to the lesion seen in?

choices.text: Dorsal column of the spinal cord

questions.solution:
From the clinical scenario, the lesion is likely seen in the cerebellum and the gait shown in the given video is a cerebellar ataxic gait. Nystagmus, intention tremors, and scanning type of speech are also other features that help in clinching the diagnosis. 

Cerebellar lesions mostly affect movement and coordination of motor activities. They are commonly seen in alcoholics, malnutrition (degeneration due to thiamine deficiency), stroke, trauma, tumor, hereditary conditions like Friedreich ataxia and other neurodegenerative disorders like multiple-system atrophy (MSA). 

 Features of cerebellar lesions are - 

  • Ataxia – Uncoordinated, intermittent jerky movements with drunken gait
  • Intention tremors
  • Nystagmus (jerky movements of the eye)
  • Speech defect – Slurring speech
  • Hypotonia or atonia – Reduced or absence of muscle tone
  • Dysmetria – Inability to judge the force and range of movement 
  • Dysdiadokokinesia – Failure to perform rapid alternating movements
  • Decomposition of movement – Lack of smooth flow of movement
  • Rebound phenomenon

Cerebellar gait ataxia as seen in the video is characterized by a wide base of support, lateral instability of the trunk, and erratic foot placement. There is a loss of balance when attempting to walk on a narrow base. Difficulty maintaining balance when turning is often an early feature. They show considerable variation in their tendency to fall in daily life.

Here, the patient is seen attempting tandem walking and displays improper heel-toe coordination, erratic foot placement, and truncal swaying.

 

Other options:

Option A: Lesions in the corticospinal tract result in spastic gait. It is characterized by stiffness in the legs, and a tendency to circumduct and scuff the feet.

Option B: Dorsal column lesions of the spinal cord result in sensory ataxia. Patients with sensory ataxia walk unsteadily with multiple falls, on a narrow base, and tend to look down while walking. They lose balance on walking with their eyes closed or in the dark. Joint sense and vibration sense are diminished.

Option C: Frontal lobe gait disorder is characterized by difficulty in initiating gait (gait ignition failure or slipping clutch gait). Typical features include wide base support, short strides with a shuffling and freezing gait, and difficulty in turning. It is commonly seen in the elderly.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with chronic heart failure presents with a particular breathing pattern. His depth and rate of respiration are plotted as given below. The type of breathing abnormality seen here is?
questions.solution:
The type of breathing abnormality shown in the image is suggestive of Cheyne-Stokes breathing. 

Cheyne-Stokes breathing is characterized by periods of waxing and waning hyperventilation separated by periods of apnea, as seen in the image. This pattern is seen at high altitudes and in patients with severe heart disease or brain injury.

 
In Cheyne-Stokes respiration, the person ventilates excessively, leading to an excessive loss of CO2 and an increased concentration of O2 in the blood. These changes in the blood are detected only after a few seconds after the pulmonary blood reaches the brain. Thus ventilation does not get inhibited immediately.
 
When the overventilated blood finally reaches the respiratory center in the brain, the center gets excessively depressed, and ventilation is inhibited. This leads to increased CO2 and decreased O2 in the alveoli. It takes the center a few more seconds to respond to these reversed changes, leading to excessive ventilation. The cycle then repeats.
 
 
In severe chronic cardiac failure, blood flow from the lungs to the brain is slow. This leads to alveolar changes in the CO2 and O2 occurring for longer than usual and excessive storage of these gases within the alveoli and pulmonary blood. After a few seconds, the periodic respiratory drive becomes extreme and Cheyne-Stokes breathing begins. 
 
Other options:
Option A: Kussmaul's breathing is a form of hyperventilation. It occurs due to an increased tidal volume with or without an increase in respiratory rate. It is seen in association with any condition that leads to acidosis.
 
Option B: Biot's breathing is characterized by regular deep respirations with periods of apnea. It occurs due to pontine damage by stroke, trauma, or uncal herniation. 
 
Option D: Hyperpnea refers to an increased volume of respiration with or without an increased rate of breathing. Blood gas concentrations are normal.

questions.text: Out of two athletes 'A' and 'B', 'A' is participating in long-distance running, and 'B' is participating in the long jump. Which of the following are the correct combination of the muscles and the type of muscle fiber that serves them best?
questions.solution:
'A' is the long-distance runner who would be best benefitting from soleus's slow-twitch fibers, and B, the long jumper would benefit from gastrocnemius's fast-twitch fibers.

Fast-twitch and slow-twitch muscle fibers

  • Fast-twitch fibers can deliver extreme amounts of power for a few seconds to a minute.
    • The enzymes that promote rapid release of energy from the phosphagen and glycogen–lactic acid energy systems are more active in fast-twitch fibers.
    • Fast-twitch fibers are about twice as large in diameter compared with slow-twitch fibers.
    • Gastrocnemius muscle has a higher preponderance of fast-twitch fibers, which gives it the capability of forceful and rapid contraction of the type used in jumping.
  • Slow-twitch fibers are mainly organized for endurance, especially for the generation of aerobic energy.
    • They have far more mitochondria than do the fast-twitch fibers.
    • They contain considerably more myoglobin. The extra myoglobin increases the rate of diffusion of oxygen throughout the fiber.
    • The enzymes of the aerobic metabolic system are considerably more active in slow-twitch fibers.
    • The number of capillaries is greater in the vicinity of slow-twitch fibers.
    • Soleus muscle has a higher preponderance of slow-twitch muscle fibers and therefore is used to a greater extent for prolonged lower leg muscle activity.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought by his mother with complaints of poor growth, weakness, abnormal gait, and bowing of the legs. The head appears as seen in the image below. Laboratory investigations revealed low serum levels of vitamin D. All of the following findings can be seen in this patient except
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, the clinical features of the patient and low serum vitamin D levels point to a diagnosis of vitamin D deficiency rickets in the patient. The image shows frontal bossing seen in rickets. This condition is associated with an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. 

Nutritional rickets commonly occur due to the deficiency of vitamin D, thereby affecting the metabolism of calcium and phosphate ions in the body. Vitamin D is mainly synthesized by the following mechanism -

This active vitamin D stimulates and increases the absorption of Ca2+  ions from the intestine. It does so by increasing the formation of calbindin which is a calcium-binding protein, that transports calcium into the cells. 

Thus, in vitamin D deficiency, low calcium levels may be seen in the blood. To raise this serum calcium, the secretion of the parathyroid hormone rises and causes - 

  • Reabsorption of calcium in the kidneys and decreases renal calcium excretion
  • Secretion of phosphate ions in exchange, leading to an increase in renal phosphate excretion 
  • Increase in bone turnover 
  • Increases the level of the enzyme 1-α hydroxylase which leads to more production of the active form of Vitamin D - 1,25 dihydro cholecalciferol.

Radiological features of rickets:

  • Delayed appearance of the epiphysis
  • Widening of growth plate: normal width of growth plate is 2-4mm. It is increased in cases of rickets due to excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of metaphysis: normally metaphysis meets epiphysis as a smooth line of sclerosis. But in rickets the line is absent and the metaphyseal ends appear irregular and the cartilage accumulating in the growth plate creates a depression in the metaphysis causing cupping.
  • Fraying: indistinct margins of the metaphysis
  • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
  • In healing rickets, zone of calcification becomes denser.

  • Wrist: especially the ulna
  • Anterior rib ends: rachitic rosary

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the correct sequence of completion of events after transection of a nerve -
  1. Myelin sheath degeneration
  2. Chromatolytic reaction
  3. Regenerative sprouting
  4. Denervation hypersensitivity
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the correct sequence is 1-2-3-4 (option A)

Wallerian degeneration is a type of orthograde degeneration triggered by an injury to the axon. These changes occur from the point of injury in the neuron and move towards the nerve terminal, thereby interrupting the functional neural transmission. 

The sequence of changes that occur:

  • Myelin sheath degeneration distal to the injury.
  • Proximal axon degeneration (retrograde - from the axon to the cell body)
  • Chromatolysis reaction- Swelling of the cell body, eccentrically placed nucleus, and fragmentation of the rough endoplasmic reticulum
  • Regenerative sprouting - neurons regrow projecting multiple small, branches. 
  • Sometimes when a motor nerve is injured, there is a marked proliferation of the nicotinic receptors making them extremely sensitive. This is known as denervation hypersensitivity.
